facts.text: This appeal brought up by special leave arises out of proceedings for assessment of agricultural Income-tax under the U.P. Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1948 (U. P. Act No. III of 1949).

anchor.surface_text: Bhargava, J. This appeal brought up by special leave arises out of proceedings for assessment of agricultural Income-tax under the U.P. Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1948  U. P. Act No. III of 1949   hereinaf

facts.text: The respondent was an agriculturist in the district of Agra.

The State Government, through the Collector of Agra, filed an application for revision against this order of the assessing authority before the Boar of Revision, Agricultural Income-tax, U.P., urging that the assessing authority had erred in allowing a deduction of the sum of Rs. 8,210-8-0 for expenses of cultivation against the sum of Rs. 5,769-12-3 actually spent and claimed by the respondent in his return.

The Revision Board, instead of deciding the question, expressed its opinion on it and referred the following question for the opinion of the Allahabad High Court An assessee files a return showing his income from and the expenses of cultivation under section 6 2  b  of the Agricultural Income-tax Act.

facts.text: The Revision Board referred the following question for the opinion of the Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Revision Board, instead of deciding the question, expressed its opinion on it and referred the following question for the opinion of the Allahabad High Court An assessee files a return showing his income from and the expenses of cultivation under section 6 2  b  of the Agricultural Income-tax Act.

facts.text: The question referred: An assessee files a return showing his income from and the expenses of cultivation under section 6(2)(b) of the Agricultural Income-tax Act. His returns are rejected and the income is determined to be much higher than what has been shown in the returns. Is it open to the assessing authority in view of the increase in the income to allow a larger amount by way of expenses than what was shown in the returns, or is the statement made in the returns binding on the assessee?

anchor.surface_text: An assessee files a return showing his income from and the expenses of cultivation under section 6 2  b  of the Agricultural Income-tax Act. His returns are rejected and the income is determined to be much higher than what has been shown in the returns. Is it open to the assessing authority in view of the increase in the income to allow a larger amount by way of expenses than what was shown in the returns, or is the statement made in the returns binding on the assessee ? The High Court answered the question in favour of the assessee- respondent, and, companysequently, the State Government has companye up in this appeal to this companyrt.

facts.text: The High Court answered the question in favour of the assessee-respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the question in favour of the assessee- respondent, and, companysequently, the State Government has companye up in this appeal to this companyrt. Mr. C. B. Agarwala, on behalf of the State, urged that in view of rule 13 framed by the U.P. Government in exercise of the rule-making power under the Act, the assessing authority was incompetent to allow as expenses any amount other than the amounts actually paid by the assessee on account of agricultural operations mentioned in that rule and since the respondent himself claimed that he actually spent the sum of Rs. 5,769-12-3, there was numberjustification for the assessing authority to allow any amount in excess of this amount as expenses of cultivation.

The companyputation of the agricultural income-tax from agricultural operations has to be made by the assessing authority in accordance with section 6 2  b  of the Act.

facts.text: The Supreme Court held that the assessing authority had full justification in estimating allowable expenditure at a higher figure than claimed by the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The assessing authority, in thus estimating the allowable expenditure at a figure higher than the amount claimed by the respondent, had full justification in the circumstances that he had estimated the produce also at a higher figure. The answer returned by the High Court was, therefore, perfectly companyrect.

facts.text: The answer returned by the High Court was perfectly correct.

anchor.surface_text: The answer returned by the High Court was, therefore, perfectly companyrect.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 13 framed by the U.P. These principles cannot, however, be held to fetter the power of the assessing authority to arrive at the companyrect figure of expenses incurred allowable under section 6 2  b  iv  of the Act.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: anyrt. Mr. C. B. Agarwala, on behalf of the State, urged that in view of rule 13 framed by the U.P. Government in exercise of the rule-making power un

arguments.court_reasoning: Rule 13 only provides ordinary principles and cannot fetter statutory duty under section 6(2)(b)(iv) to determine actual expenses incurred.

arguments.claim: Under section 6(2)(b)(iv), the assessing authority must allow expenses incurred in raising the crop, making it fit for market, transporting it, without limitation that expenses must be proved as amounts of money actually paid.

anchor.surface_text: The companyputation of the agricultural income-tax from agricultural operations has to be made by the assessing authority in accordance with section 6 2  b  of the Act. Under sub-clause  iv  of that provision, the assessing authority, in calculating the assessable agricultural income, has to allow the expenses incurred in the previous year in raising the crop from which the agricultural income is derived, in making it fit for market and in transporting it to market, including the maintenance or hire of agricultural implements and cattle require for these purposes. It is to be numbericed that under this provision companytained in the Act itself, there is numberlimitation that the expenses must be proved to be amounts of money actually paid

arguments.claim: Rule 13 can only be interpreted as laying down principles for ordinarily determining expenses under section 6(2)(b)(iv), but cannot fetter the assessing authority's power to arrive at the correct figure of allowable expenses.

anchor.surface_text: for any specified operations. What this provision companytemplates is that the assessing authority must determine the expenses incurred in raising the crop and on operations leading to its sale. Rule 13 framed by the U.P. Government can only be interpreted as laying down the principles according to which the assessing authority must ordinarily determine the expenses incurred for the purpose of deduction under section 6 2  b  iv  of the Act. These principles cannot, however, be held to fetter the power of the assessing authority to arrive at the companyrect figure of expenses incurred allowable under section 6 2  b  iv  of the Act.

arguments.claim: Assessing authority had full justification to estimate allowable expenses higher than claimed by respondent because the claim was based on lower yield estimate while authority estimated higher yield and corresponding higher expenses.

anchor.surface_text: In the case before us, the expenses by the respondent had been claimed on the basis of a yield which according to the assessing authority, was lower than the actual yield. The assessing authority, therefore, estimated the produce at a higher figure, and we do number see any reason why, when the assessing authority estimated that the produce was higher than that shown by the respondents, he companyld number also estimate that the expenses incurred in respect of that higher produce must have been larger than the amount actually shown by the respondent. The assessing authority, in thus estimating the allowable expenditure at a figure higher than the amount claimed by the respondent, had full justification in the circumstances that he had estimated the produce also at a higher figure. The answer returned by the High Court was, therefore, perfectly companyrect.

holdings.text: Under sub-clause (iv) of that provision, the assessing authority, in calculating the assessable agricultural income, has to allow the expenses incurred in the previous year in raising the crop from which the agricultural income is derived, in making it fit for market and in transporting it to market, including the maintenance or hire of agricultural implements and cattle required for these purposes. It is to be noticed that under this provision contained in the Act itself, there is no limitation that the expenses must be proved to be amounts of money actually paid for any specified operations.

anchor.surface_text: sub-clause  iv  of that provision, the assessing authority, in calculating the assessable agricultural income, has to allow the expenses incurred in the previous year in raising the crop from which the agricultural income is derived, in making it fit for market and in transporting it to market, including the maintenance or hire of agricultural implements and cattle require for these purposes. It is to be noticed that under this provision companytained in the Act itself, there is numberlimitation that the expenses must be proved to be amounts of money actually paid

holdings.reasoning_summary: The plain language of section 6(2)(b)(iv) mandates allowance of all expenses incurred without requiring proof of actual monetary payments.

holdings.text: Rule 13 framed by the U.P. Government can only be interpreted as laying down the principles according to which the assessing authority must ordinarily determine the expenses incurred for the purpose of deduction under section 6(2)(b)(iv) of the Act. These principles cannot, however, be held to fetter the power of the assessing authority to arrive at the correct figure of expenses incurred allowable under section 6(2)(b)(iv) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: for any specified operations. What this provision contemplates is that the assessing authority must determine the expenses incurred in raising the crop and on operations leading to its sale. Rule 13 framed by the U.P. Government can only be interpreted as laying down the principles according to which the assessing authority must ordinarily determine the expenses incurred for the purpose of deduction under section 6 2  b  iv  of the Act. These principles cannot, however, be held to fetter the power of the assessing authority to arrive at the correct figure of expenses incurred allowable under section 6 2  b  iv  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: As a subordinate rule, Rule 13 provides ordinary guidelines but cannot limit the statutory duty under section 6(2)(b)(iv) to compute actual allowable expenses.

holdings.text: Rule 13 framed by the U.P. Government can only be interpreted as laying down the principles according to which the assessing authority must ordinarily determine the expenses incurred for the purpose of deduction under section 6(2)(b)(iv) of the Act. These principles cannot, however, be held to fetter the power of the assessing authority to arrive at the correct figure of expenses incurred allowable under section 6(2)(b)(iv) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: for any specified operations. What this provision contemplates is that the assessing authority must determine the expenses incurred in raising the crop and on operations leading to its sale. Rule 13 framed by the U.P. Government can only be interpreted as laying down the principles according to which the assessing authority must ordinarily determine the expenses incurred for the purpose of deduction under section 6 2  b  iv  of the Act. These principles cannot, however, be held to fetter the power of the assessing authority to arrive at the correct figure of expenses incurred allowable under section 6 2  b  iv  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 13 subordinate to Act; interpreted to guide but not restrict statutory power to determine correct expenses.

holdings.text: The assessing authority, in thus estimating the allowable expenditure at a figure higher than the amount claimed by the respondent, had full justification in the circumstances that he had estimated the produce also at a higher figure. The answer returned by the High Court was, therefore, perfectly correct.

anchor.surface_text: In the case before us, the expenses by the respondent had been claimed on the basis of a yield which according to the assessing authority, was lower than the actual yield. The assessing authority, therefore, estimated the produce at a higher figure, and we do not see any reason why, when the assessing authority estimated that the produce was higher than that shown by the respondents, he could not also estimate that the expenses incurred in respect of that higher produce must have been larger than the amount actually shown by the respondent. The assessing authority, in thus estimating the allowable expenditure at a figure higher than the amount claimed by the respondent, had full justification in the circumstances that he had estimated the produce also at a higher figure. The answer returned by the High Court was, therefore, perfectly correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejecting return and estimating higher produce justifies estimating proportionally higher expenses under section 6(2)(b)(iv); High Court answer affirmed.
